ALLEGATION:
Agency moved forward with finalizing an adoption prior to having the final Adoption
Assistance Agreements signed by the AGAO Program Manager.
2

INVESTIGATION:
I interviewed the Program Director on 01/21/2022 regarding the allegation. She
reported yes, the allegation is true. She said Adoption Worker 1 filed for subsidy on
7/20/21, which the subsidy department provided initial subsidy agreement to
Adoption Worker 1 as of 9/2/21. Following the subsidy agreement, it was provided to
the relative to sign, with initial technical issues, the signed agreement was provided
to the Adoption Worker by the relative on 9/15/21. Adoption Worker 1 then uploaded
the email confirmation into MiSACWIS. However, the adoption worker inadvertently
did not upload the signed agreement or send the subsidy department an email to
confirm. She said this was later caught during the request for subsidy case opening.
She said Adoption Worker 1 filed the adoption petition on 9/15/21, through Monroe
County Court’s Adoption Department and confirmed drop off via email. The Program
Director said after numerous email exchanges and getting documents signed a
finalization hearing was scheduled for 10/28/21. She said it wasn’t until the final
orders were received and the case closure process began that the error was
identified on 11/17/21.
The Program Director provided a guideline of what occurred that caused the
allegation to occur. The guideline is as follows:
7/20/20201; Subsidy Requested
9/02/2021; Received and Sent Relative Subsidy Agreement to review and sign
9/15/2021; Relative returned signed Subsidy Agreement / Worker Uploaded
Email Confirmation into MiSACWIS
10/07/2021; OTR/OPC issued
10/28/2021; Adoption Finalized
11/11/2021; Adoption Case Opening Requested via email
11/17/2021; Subsidy informed Adoption worker via email, signed initial subsidy
agreements were not received by the Subsidy office and thus a final contract was
not issued
11/17/2021; Adoption worker then immediately informed supervisor
11/19/2021; Contacted subsidy office regarding the Issue
The Program Director said to rectify the issue with the assistance of the adoption
supervisor, program manager, and director of the agency multiple parties were
contacted to begin the process. First the adoption worker contacted the MDHHS
foster care worker to explain the issue in hopes of getting some assistance. The
Program Director said the adoptive mother was contacted the same day 11/17/21
and informed of the issue. She said the next step were to contact the Lawyer
Guardians Ad Litem (LGAL), Monroe County’s Special Prosecutor, and court’s
adoption supervisor who were emailed on 11/19/21. She said Monroe County parities
provided direction and provided a motion to relieve the order on 11/23/21 and
11/24/21. The Monroe Court scheduler then provided a court date on12/20/21. The
Program Director said the previous order of adoption was rescinded and the updated
order of adoption was authorized for 12/20/21. Once the order of adoption was
3

received the adoption worker contacted subsidy department and uploaded
appropriate documentation to request subsidy case opening. She said as soon as the
error was identified her agency began working on solving the issue immediately to
get it rectified.
I interviewed the Adoption Worker, Adoption Supervisor and Program Manager.
They had no additional information to add. However, the Program Director said the
agency paid the adoptive parent the amount in subsidy that she would have received
from the order terminating rights/order placing child (OTR/OPC) until the subsidy
contracts were finalized to assist in providing relief.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12207 Staff responsibilities.
(3) An agency shall require that social service workers be
directly responsible for all of the following activities:
(a) Placing and supervising children in out-of-home care.
Social service workers shall work directly with the children,
their families, and other relevant individuals and be
primarily responsible for the development, implementation,
and review of service plans for the children and their
families.
ANALYSIS: Based on documentation of the case records and the interviews
with the Program Director who admitted that an error was made
on the agency behalf. The agency took full responsibility for the
error however, the agency failed to follow the responsibility of
implementing the sign contract for the adoption assistance
programs which cause the agency to rescind the previous order
of adoption. Therefore, the agency is found in violation with this
rule.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
